required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Role of Glycation and Inflammation in Acute Ischemic Heart Disease
clinical_study.official_title: Action of Glycation and Inflammation in Operative Ischemic Heart Disease

brief_summary.textblock: This study requires the consecutive enrollment of 60 patients following the first event of acute myocardial infarction, evaluating B-Cell Activating Factor (BAFF) and methylglyoxal (MGO) levels in the acute setting (pre-reperfusion) and 3 months after reperfusion.

detailed_description.textblock: This study requires the consecutive enrollment of 60 patients at admission for first acute myocardial infarction. At enrollment, before reperfusion, a blood sample is obtained to measure B-Cell Activating Factor (BAFF) and methylglyoxal (MGO) levels in the acute setting. This measure is then repeated at follow-up visit 3 months after reperfusion. The aim of the study is to identify specific subsets of patients and evaluate biomarkers variations.

primary_outcome.measure: Identification of Inflammatory Biomarkers (BAFF) linked to ischemic event and outcome
Identification of Glycation Biomarkers (MGO) linked to ischemic event and outcome

secondary_outcome.measure: Identification of biomarkers variations (BAFF) complications and outcome
Identification of biomarkers variations (MGO) complications and outcome

arm_group.description: Measurement of BAFF and MGO at hospitalization (before reperfusion) and after 3 months during follow-up

intervention.description: measurement of BAFF and MGO levels before reperfusion and after 3 months

study_pop.textblock: 60 consecutive patients admitted in the ED for first myocardial infarction who meet eligibility criteria

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- hospitalization for first myocardial infarction (STEMI or NSTEMI)
- age between 18 and 80
Exclusion Criteria:
- uncompensated T2DM (HbA1c >53mmol/mol)
- use of anti-CD20 treatment
- chronic anti-inflammatory treatment for autoimmune disease (i.e. DMARDs, high dose FANS, cortisonic drugs)
